question: The obvious question, I guess following this is, how does the man with his background a couple of gun-related incidents, discharged from the army of a pattern of misconduct, how does he get clearance to enter one of the most secured military bases in America and do what he did?
answer: He had a pass that apparently allowed him to enter the day the Yard that's right behind me.

question: Now, there are 3,000 people who work at the base, how secure is it would you say?
answer: Well, I thought the base was very secured.

question: I'm told there are armed security guards, armed police that the civilians that worked there are not allowed to carry a gun, is that correct?
answer: Yeah.

question: Are you aware of their presence?
answer: Yeah, there are security guards inside the building, outside the buildings, around the building as you enter the gate.

question: But he was carrying an AR- 15 assault rifle, another rifle and a handgun, would somebody carrying weapons in the way that he was immediately ring alarm bells inside the base?
answer: Well, I don't know how he was able to get in on the base.

question: Because presumably -- presumably Patricia, you have to go through some kind of security check to get inside the building?
answer: When you come inside the gate, yes, you have to show your cache (ph) card.

question: Do you need to go through metal detectors?
answer: No, we don't have any metal detectors.

question: Are you going back to work Patricia tomorrow?
answer: No, I will not.

question: What is your feeling towards the man that put you through this and so many of your colleagues?
answer: I'm terrified.

question: On the one hand, he seems quite shy and very well-behaved, never caused any trouble, on the other, a little clue here and there incidents involving firearms, misconduct later being discharged from the Navy, who is the real Aaron Alexis?
answer: That picture really is just emerging Piers.

question: How could somebody like this with this background just walk on to a base, on to the tip like this, and get inside and be in a position to kill all these people?
answer: Oh, yes.

question: Tell me, what prompted you to react like that and expand on what you were saying?
answer: Well, you know, Piers, I'm a doctor.

question: How many of you been treating the way you are and what is the current set of their condition?
answer: Sure, I'd be happy to tell you.

question: Shawn Henry, in terms of the investigation and from all that you gleaned to date, are we dealing, do you think definitely with a long shooter here?
answer: I don't know that you can make the determination right now.

question: It did some sort of old state of affairs that the FBI seeking information after the shooter is dead, what do you make of that?
answer: I think that that's actually the right protocol.

question: And are you even more surprised as I am that he's able to walk fully armed into a base of his nature and do what he did?
answer: ENRY: Well, I don't know that it's clear right now how he actually got the weapons on to the base whether he was in some type of the work track; I'm not clear on what his access was.

question: How on earth do you justify that tweet?
answer: Well look at DC, first of all in DC you're not allowed to own any semiautomatic rifle.

question: Where did he buy the M-15?
answer: Well, we don't know where he bought it.

question: Do you know that he bought it?
answer: Because I'm telling a fact Ben.

question: Why do you think that's not a problem here?
answer: Well, there is a problem here, Piers, when our failure as a nation is to even talk about the complexity of the problem.

question: Is that right?
answer: On this case.

question: You are saying they are inventing those statistics?
answer: I'm saying multiple people have said that they're wrong in terms of their numbers.

question: Is that what your opposition?
answer: OTT: No, I didn't say they didn't happen.

question: Is there -- Is it really necessary?
answer: Of those, 30 have happened since 2006.

question: What does make them wrong John Lott?
answer: You can -- Professor Fox at Northeastern University, others have looked at this and they would warn you to be careful not to use those numbers.

question: Can it be as simple as that or are we talking about somebody with an underlying serious mental health issue?
answer: It might be as simple as that.

question: Could that in any way had been partly had trigger for what happened?
answer: Absolutely.

question: But anger manifested into violence by a gun?
answer: Absolutely.

question: What's the answer?
answer: Well, I think the answer is to really takes a look at these cases and see are there common threads in there.

question: What is your reaction?
answer: Well, here is one thing it was shocking to me and it go back a lot of memories from November 5th 2009.

question: If you can't even get those kind of things in any kind of sensible gun control legislation what hope is there?
answer: Well, right now, today it appears that there is no hope, but there is hope and there's light at the end of tunnel.

question: It is the preferred mass shooters weapon of choice, and yet I don't see any logical reason and you're a military man why any civilian needs to have one of these killing machines?
answer: Well, a lot of civilians they purchase one because what you have to look at, Piers is that a lot of times different fractions glorify in AR15 or in automatic rifle.
